I would recommend "Super". It is a superhero film directed by Marc Webb and starring Chris Pratt, Zoe Saldana, Michael B Jordan, Dan Dugan, and Jeff Pidgeon.
The plot of the movie revolves around Clark Kent (Chris Pratt) and Lois Lane (Zoe Saldana) who are superheroes in Metropolis. Their job is to protect the citizens of Metropolis from various threats such as supervillains, alien invasions, and other dangers that might threaten the safety and well-being of the citizens of Metropolis.
In order to protect their city, Clark Kent and Lois Lane embark on a series of adventures and missions to stop various threats that might endanger the safety and well-being of the citizens of Metropolis.
One of the main themes of "Super" is the concept of "superheroing". This refers to the idea of using one's abilities, skills, knowledge, expertise, experience, or whatever resources or assets one possesses in order to help oneself or others, protect oneself or others, prevent oneself or others from being harmed or injured, save oneself or others, or perform any other actions or deeds that might be beneficial for oneself or others.
One of the main themes of "Super" is also the concept of "superpower". This refers to the idea of having one's own abilities, skills, knowledge, expertise, experience, or whatever resources or assets one possesses in order to help oneself or others, protect oneself or others, prevent oneself or others from being harmed or injured, save oneself or others, or perform any other actions or deeds that might be beneficial for oneself or others.
Another main theme of "Super" is also the concept of "superhero". This refers to the idea of having one's own abilities, skills, knowledge, expertise, experience, or whatever resources or assets one possesses in order to help oneself or others, protect oneself or others, prevent oneself or others from being harmed or injured, save oneself or others, or perform any other actions or deeds that might be beneficial for oneself or others.
Overall, the main themes of "Super" are the concepts of "superheroing", "superpower", and "superhero".

Based on the user's preference cues, I would recommend "The Relic" (1997) and "The Stuff" (N/)/). 

Both movies are based on the same premise: a mysterious, gooey substance is discovered by farmers in a village exploited by bandits. The farmers hire a veteran samurai for protection, who gathers six other samurai to join him. 

In both movies, the main character (in this case, a veteran samurai) must navigate a dangerous and unpredictable world that is threatened by the arrival of a mysterious, gooey substance. 

Overall, both movies offer an exciting and engaging adventure that will keep viewers on the edge of their seats.

conversation.speaker: SYSTEM
conversation.text: Based on the preferences given, I would recommend "The Andromeda Strain" which is a science fiction thriller film from 1971. The movie follows a group of scientists who are working feverishly in a secret, state-of-the-art laboratory to discover what killed the citizens of a small town and how the deadly contagion can be stopped. The movie stars Paula Kelly, David Wayne, David Wayne, Eric Christmas. I would also recommend "Waiting" which is a drama film from 1999. The movie follows Clare who is an artist who agrees to bear a child for another couple. As we see the characters and their relationships develop, Clare begins to have second thoughts about giving up her baby. Her mixed emotions are further confused by the arrival of an old boyfriend who wants to marry her. What will she decide to do? The movie stars Genevieve O'Reilly, Ash Cook, James Nesbitt. Lastly, I would recommend "The Secret" which is a drama film from 1992. The movie follows a stranger who enters into and forever alters the life of a couple. He claims to be pursued by certain authorities who intend to prevent him from disclosing a secret that only he holds, whence the title. Is he lying, or insane  - or is he telling the truth? Who, if anyone, is after him? And what  *is*  - the secret? The movie stars Genevieve O'Reilly, Ash Cook, James Nesbitt.
